title: A Wall-Street bear in Europe :
author: Young, Samuel.
snippet: Some were shaped like temples ; and one in particular, an exact copy of the Temple of Ceres at Psestum, was well done.

title: Essays critical and imaginative,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: What Sir Humphry means here by "an uncultivated tree," we know no better than himself;  but the dew and spray of which he speaks, and the running waters, do minister to the wild — and to many — all the creatures of the wild — as useful then as it is when flowing  in the plain below, gladdening the yellow Ceres.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: What Sir Humphry means here by " an uncultivated tree," we know no better than himself  ; but the dew and spray of which he speaks, and the running waters, do minister to the wild — and to many — all the creatures of the wild — as useful then as it is when flowing  in the plain below, gladdening the yellow Ceres.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: west of the city, on the beach, is a well,mentioned by Pausanias as the oracular-fountain of Ceres.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The fane of Ceres is finished with the greatest accuracy and beauty of proportion and taste, and in looking upon it I forgot all the unpleasant feelings which at first oppressed me.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A second temple in the same style was dedicated to Ceres as the large one was to Neptune, on whose dominion they Jooked, and who was the tutelar deity of Paestum, and so called from one of his Greek names.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Now I had some base thoughts concerning luncheon, which was most munificently  supplied by Surtees [at his rooms in University College], with the aid of the best ale I ever drank in my life, the real wine of Ceres, and worth that of Bacchus.

title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: (It was my strange, lucky fortune, by the way, that summer of '65, to see the cradle of the American  harvester swung on the wheat -fields of New Jersey and New England, then to see the sickle performing the same office on those of Central and Southern Enorland, then alona: the willowed water-courses of Normandy, in France, and yet again over Northumberland and on the fertile uplands of the Scottish Lothians — a succession of harvest scenes which almost made me believe that Ceres had taken me by the hand and was leading me round the world to show me her treasures I) The harvest, I say, stood yet on the broad Cheshire  fields.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Sent off the squib to Barnes, "An Ode to the Goddess Ceres."

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Now I had some base thoughts concerning luncheon, which was most munificently supplied by Surtees, at his rooms in University College, with the aid of the best ale I ever drank in my life, the real wine of Ceres, and worth that of Bacchus.

title: The history of a man.
author: Gilfillan, George
snippet: Some astronomers held that those little planets — Juno, Ceres, Vesta, and the rest — were worlds which Nature had tiied to make, but had failed somehow.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: I told a Scotch gentleman that such a profound silence resembled the ancient procession of the Roman matrons in honour of Ceres ; and the Scotch gentleman  told me (and, faith, I believe he was right) that I was a very great pedant for my pains.' * *

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: When Rathillet and his friends were about to disperse, in sullen disappointment, the wife of a farmer at Baldinny sent a lad to tell them, that the Archbishop's coach was upon the road returning from Ceres towards St. Andrews.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: When Rathiliet and his friends were about to disperse, in sullen disappointment, the wife of a farmerat Baldinny sent a lad lo tell them, that the Archbishop's coach was upon the road returning fromCeres towards St Andrew's.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: (It was my strange, lucky fortune, bythe way, that summer of '65, to see the cradle of the Amer-ican harvester swung on the wheat-fields of New Jersey andNew England, then to see the sickle performing the sameoffice on those of Central and Southern England, then alongthe willowed water-courses of Normandy, in France, and yetagain over Northumberland and on the fertile uplands of theScottish Lothians—a succession of harvest scenes whichalmost made me believe that Ceres had taken me by thehand and was leading me round the world to show me hertreasures!) The harvest, I say, stood yet on the broad Ches-hire fields.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: "Where Ceres gilds the fertile plain,And richly waves the yellow grain ;And Lomond hill wi' misty showersAft weets auld Falkland's roj-al towers."
